summary: This is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, dated August 8, 2019. It designates his executors, outlines the administration of his estate, and bequeaths all his property to The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2018 Trust. The document establishes broad powers for the executors and includes a no-contest clause. This is the final pages of Jeffrey E. Epstein's Last Will and Testament, dated May 8, 2018. It details tax apportionment provisions, execution formalities, and includes the signing and witnessing of the document. The document establishes the legal framework for the distribution of his estate.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's will, signed on August 8, 2019, bequeaths his entire estate to 'The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2018 Trust'.
The primary executors named are Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn, with Kathryn H. Ruemmler as the successor executor.
Each executor is to be paid $250,000 upon completion of probate, with no other compensation for serving as executor.
The will grants the executors extremely broad powers to manage, invest, sell, and litigate regarding the estate's assets without needing judicial approval.
The document includes a 'no-contest' clause, disinheriting any beneficiary who challenges the will or the trust.
Jeffrey E. Epstein executed his Last Will and Testament on May 8, 2018.
The will contains detailed provisions for the apportionment of federal and state estate taxes, including taxes on assets not directly passing under the will or its associated trust.
The document was notarized by Habibe Avdiu, a Notary Public for the State of New York.
The will references a separate 'Trust Agreement' which is incorporated by reference for the disposition of the majority of his estate.
The document includes standard legal clauses regarding the lapse of bequests to predeceased beneficiaries and definitions of key terms like 'Executor' and 'Trustee'.
